gkwreg 1.0.1.9000
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models

    Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model

    gkwreg.Rd

    Fits a regression model for data bounded between 0 and 1 using the Generalized Kumaraswamy (GKw) distribution. In this model, all five parameters (\(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\gamma\), \(\delta\), \(\lambda\)) can be linked to covariates through distinct linear predictors and user-specified inverse link functions. The flexible structure of the model allows for a wide range of applications, including situations where the response variable exhibits complex bounded behavior.

    gkwreg(
  formula,
  data,
  link = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 1),
  scale = c(10, 10, 10, 10, 10),
  start = NULL,
  control = list(),
  weights = NULL,
  subset = NULL,
  na.action = getOption("na.action", na.omit),
  offset = NULL,
  model = TRUE,
  x = TRUE,
  y = TRUE,
  silent = TRUE
)

    Arguments

    formula

    A Formula object of the form y ~ alpha_terms | beta_terms | gamma_terms | delta_terms | lambda_terms, where each part on the right specifies the covariates for the corresponding parameter. Missing parts are automatically replaced with intercept-only models.

    data

    A data frame containing the variables referenced in the formula.

    link

    Numeric vector of length 5 specifying the link function for each parameter (in order: \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\gamma\), \(\delta\), \(\lambda\)). Valid values: 1 (log), 2 (logit), 3 (probit), 4 (cauchy), 5 (cloglog), 6 (identity), 7 (sqrt), 8 (inverse), and 9 (inverse-square). Default is c(1, 1, 1, 1, 1) (log for all).

    scale

    Numeric vector of length 5 with scale factors for each link function that maps to (0,1). Default is c(10, 10, 10, 10, 10).

    start

    Optional list with initial values for the regression coefficients, whose components are beta1, beta2, beta3, beta4, and beta5. If NULL (default), attempts to estimate plausible initial values from the data.

    control

    List of control parameters for optimization. Available components (defaults in parentheses):

    • optimizer: ("nlminb") Optimization method: "nlminb" or "optim".

    • optim.method: ("BFGS") Method for optim if optimizer="optim".

    • eval.max: (5000) Maximum function evaluations.

    • iter.max: (5000) Maximum iterations.

    • abs.tol: (1e-20) Absolute tolerance.

    • rel.tol: (1e-10) Relative tolerance.

    • trace: (1 if silent=FALSE, else 0) Level of progress messages.

    • inner.method: ("newton") TMB internal method.

    • inner.maxit: (4000) Maximum internal iterations in TMB.

    • smartsearch: (TRUE) Smart search in TMB internal optimizer.

    • tmb.silent: (value of silent) Suppresses TMB internal messages.

    • hessian: (TRUE) Calculate Hessian matrix?

    • openmp: (TRUE) Use OpenMP if available?

    weights

    (NOT USED BY THE C++ CODE) Numeric vector of weights (not used).

    subset

    Optional expression indicating which rows of data to use.

    na.action

    Function for handling missing values in the data frame. Default is na.omit.

    offset

    Optional vector of offsets to be included in the linear predictor for parameter \(\alpha\). If not NULL, this column is added as an offset.

    model

    Logical indicating whether to return the model frame. Default: TRUE.

    x

    Logical indicating whether to return the model matrices. Default: TRUE.

    y

    Logical indicating whether to return the response vector. Default: TRUE.

    silent

    Logical; if TRUE, suppresses progress messages. Default: FALSE.

    Value

    An object of class "gkwreg" containing (among others):

    • call and formula: Original calls.

    • coefficients: List with regression coefficient estimates.

    • fitted.values: Fitted values (predicted means).

    • residuals: Residuals (in this case, y - fitted).

    • fitted_parameters: Estimated mean values of \(\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta,\lambda\).

    • link_functions, link_codes, scale_factors: Information about link types.

    • opt, sdreport: TMB outputs.

    • loglik, aic, bic, deviance, df.residual: Fit statistics.

    • rmse, efron_r2, mean_absolute_error: Performance metrics.

    • cache_performance: Size and hit rate of internal cache, if available.

    • vcov: Variance-covariance matrix of parameters.

    • nobs, npar: Number of observations and parameters.

    • converged, iterations: Convergence and number of iterations.

    • data, model_matrices, y: If requested, returns data, model matrices, and response.

    • weights, offset: If passed, returned here for reference (but weights don't enter the fit).

    • model: The TMB object created (compiled model).

    Details

    The GKw distribution is defined for \(y \in (0,1)\) by the probability density function:

    $$ f(y; \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \lambda) = \frac{\lambda \alpha \beta\, y^{\alpha-1}\,(1-y^\alpha)^{\beta-1}}{B(\gamma, \delta+1)} \Bigl[1-(1-y^\alpha)^\beta\Bigr]^{\gamma\lambda-1} \Bigl\{1-\Bigl[1-(1-y^\alpha)^\beta\Bigr]^\lambda\Bigr\}^{\delta}, $$

    where \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \lambda > 0\) and \(B(\gamma, \delta+1)\) denotes the complete Beta function. The associated cumulative distribution function is:

    $$ F(y; \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \lambda) = I_{[1-(1-y^\alpha)^\beta]^\lambda}(\gamma, \delta+1), $$

    where \(I_z(a,b)\) is the regularized incomplete Beta function.

    In the regression framework, each parameter is modeled as a function of covariates through a linear predictor and an inverse link function:

    $$ \theta_i = g_\theta^{-1}\bigl(\mathbf{x}_{\theta i}^T \boldsymbol{\beta}_\theta\bigr), \quad \theta \in \{\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \lambda\}, $$

    where \(\mathbf{x}_{\theta i}\) represents the covariate vector for the \(i\)th observation corresponding to parameter \(\theta\) and \(\boldsymbol{\beta}_\theta\) is the associated regression coefficient vector.

    The GKw model is a flexible generalization that can model a variety of shapes and is particularly useful for data with skewness, bimodality, or complex behaviors within the (0,1) interval.

    Available link functions for each parameter include:

    • Log (1): \(g^{-1}(x) = \exp(x)\)

    • Logit (2): \(g^{-1}(x) = \text{scale} \cdot \frac{\exp(x)}{1+\exp(x)}\)

    • Probit (3): \(g^{-1}(x) = \text{scale} \cdot \Phi(x)\)

    • Cauchy (4): \(g^{-1}(x) = \text{scale} \cdot \Bigl(\frac{1}{\pi}\arctan(x) + \frac{1}{2}\Bigr)\)

    • Cloglog (5): \(g^{-1}(x) = \text{scale} \cdot \bigl(1 - \exp(-\exp(x))\bigr)\)

    • Identity (6): \(g^{-1}(x) = x\)

    • Square Root (7): \(g^{-1}(x) = x^2\)

    • Inverse (8): \(g^{-1}(x) = 1/x\)

    • Inverse-Square (9): \(g^{-1}(x) = 1/\sqrt{x}\)

    For link functions 2-5, which map to (0,1), the scale parameter is used to scale the result to the desired domain.

    The implementation uses the TMB (Template Model Builder) package for efficient parameter estimation through automatic differentiation, allowing for fitting complex models even with large datasets.

    References

    Kumaraswamy, P. (1980). A generalized probability density function for double-bounded random processes. Journal of Hydrology, 46(1-2), 79-88.

    Cordeiro, G. M., & de Castro, M. (2011). A new family of generalized distributions. Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, 81(7), 883-898.

    Jones, M. C. (2009). Kumaraswamy's distribution: A beta-type distribution with some tractability advantages. Statistical Methodology, 6(1), 70-81.

    See also

    gamlss for generalized additive models for location, scale, and shape.

    betareg for beta regression, another approach for modeling bounded data.

    zoib for zero-one inflated beta regression models.

    Author

    Lopes, J. E.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Load required packages
library(Formula)

# Simulate data from a beta distribution (for illustration)
set.seed(123)
n <- 1000
x1 <- rnorm(n)
x2 <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)

# True parameters
alpha <- exp(0.5 + 0.3 * x1)
beta <- exp(0.8 - 0.4 * x2)

# Generate y from Beta(alpha, beta) as a proxy for GKw data
y <- rbeta(n, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)

# Create data frame
dat <- data.frame(y = y, x1 = x1, x2 = x2)

# Fit GKw model with alpha and beta parameters linked to covariates
# gamma, delta, and lambda as intercept-only
fit <- gkwreg(
  formula = y ~ x1 | x2 | 1 | 1 | 1,
  data = dat,
  link = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 1), # log for all
  scale = c(10, 10, 10, 10, 10)
)

# Model summary
summary(fit)

# Estimated coefficients
coef(fit)

# Fitted values and residuals
head(fitted(fit))
head(residuals(fit))

# Diagnostics
plot(fit)
} # }
